abstract.p: Wilma Askinas letter on June 4 article holds candidates' focus on looks and personality rather than issues is direct result of women's vote and television (S)1

block.p: According to ''Political Overdose Alert'' [June 4], Democrats and Republicans alike need only big doses of money to pump up candidates.
To my way of thinking, money seems to flow easily; every day I read about new donations.
According to ''Political Overdose Alert'' [June 4], Democrats and Republicans alike need only big doses of money to pump up candidates.
To my way of thinking, money seems to flow easily; every day I read about new donations.
But politicians need much more to win an election: a good head of hair, a large wardrobe and a sparkling set of teeth.
This new emphasis on persnal attraction is a direct result of two factors: the women's vote and television.
Back in the old days, a candidate could look messy and get away with it. In some cases, it helped to look a little seedy.
Not anymore. Nowadays men running for office need a pair of clean but slightly tattered khakis to wear while addressing labor groups, and a Brooks Brothers suit to speak on the ladies' club circuit.
Teeth are imporant. It is practically impossible to look honest on television without denture caps.
And one can't be fat. Years ago, successful politicians were on the chubby side. Voters figured, quite logically, that a man with a big belly would not steal as much as a thin, hungry man.
Glamour plays a big part in this election. A candidate does not need a head anymore; all he needs is a good toupee.
